name: tau Cet
scenarioDescription:
The tau Cet Exoplanetary System

tau Cet is a star with 0.78 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.875 times its radius. It is located 11.74 light years away from the solar system.

tau Cet is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

tau Cet g

tau Cet g was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.00 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, tau Cet.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.06, which means that when tau Cet g is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.13 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.14. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of tau Cet g is 1.75 times the mass of Earth. At 1.75 Earth masses, tau Cet g is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

tau Cet h was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 49.41 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, tau Cet.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.23, which means that when tau Cet h is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.19 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.30. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of tau Cet h is 1.83 times the mass of Earth. At 1.83 Earth masses, tau Cet h is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

tau Cet e

tau Cet e was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.54 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 162.87 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, tau Cet.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.18, which means that when tau Cet e is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.44 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.63. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of tau Cet e is 3.93 times the mass of Earth. At 3.93 Earth masses, tau Cet e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.538 astronomical units, and a mass of 3.93 Earth masses, tau Cet e could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.

tau Cet f was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.33 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 636.13 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, tau Cet.

No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system tau Cet, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Multiple Observatories.
